description.narrative: Sida collaborates with SIWI, KappAhl, Lindex and Indiska in order to reduce the use of water, energy and chemicals in the indian textile and leather industry. The objective of the projedct is to implement Swedish Textile Water Ininitiative guidelines for sustainable water and chemical management in 39 textile factories and industries.

Sida samarbetar med SIWI KappAhl, Lindex och Indiska för att minska vatten-, energi- och kemikalienavändningen i textilindustrin i Indien. Syftet är att implementera Swedish Textile Water Initiative's riktlinjer för hållbar vattenanvändning i textilindustrin hos 39 textil-producenter. Insatsen finansieras 2013 av 15512 (Indien) och 2014 från konto 15471 (ENICT)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The SWAR-project was evaluated during 2015 which concludes the following:
The strategic targets set to achieve the project’s objective “to improve water and waste water management in textile production wet processes which entail saving energy and decrease the amount of chemicals used where applicable” were all exceeded, except for the cost savings target. For instance, the water savings amounted to more than twice the expected volume, and the number of workers participating in awareness sessions widely exceeded what was projected. 42 factories participated, which contributed to saving 284 million litres of water and 402 tonnes of chemicals. The fact that the cost saving target was not met is a bit puzzling, especially since the RoIs were impressively high at production unit level. The evaluation concludes that this may have been due to the fact that the targets for water, chemicals and energy may have been a bit unabitious while the target for overall cost-savings were over-ambitious. This together with the fact that there was an initial reluctance towards financial investments for resource savings and the fact that those (still limited number of) factories that chose to invest, started with the low-hanging, low-cost investments that rendered high returns.
The evaluation conludes that SWAR contributed to awareness raising, capacity development and adoption of new technologies that, in turn, contributed to significant reductions in resource use among the participating suppliers and sub-suppliers and set in motion a process of change in the participating factories. Furthermore, beside the reported results, there are indications that significant multiplier and spin-off effects are emerging beyond the reported direct impact of SWAR.
By joining forces in a strategic partnership like the Public Private Development Partnership it was possible to address systemic challenges in the industry that are impossible to change by one actor alone. The modality and the time and space that this created to step out of the commercial sphere and focus on the environmental aspects of the business; getting technical expertise and guidance on ‘how to go about it’, created the synergies and possibilities for triggering a change process.
Furthermore, SWAR was nominated to the GLASA awards and won the sustainiability prize at the Habit Fashion Awards in November 2015.
SWAR was designed as a two-year pilot project with the aim to extend the work beyond 2014 through scaling-up – to other countries, with more brands and suppliers involved. During 2014, SIWI and STWI worked to develop the SWAR business model for replication elsewhere. As a result of discussions with Sida, new units in India, Bangladesh, China, Turkey, and Ethiopia were welcomed to a larger version of SWAR, called STWI Projects today involving over 20 companies.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
